flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • matching transformer
Tools
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Shears
  • Stapler Gun
  • Wire cutter/stripper

lines.text: My wife LOVES the Summer Olympics. However, we don't have cable. I need to find a way for her to be able to watch. Of course, we could just get cable... but what fun is that?!
lines.text_raw: My wife LOVES the Summer Olympics. However, we don't have cable. I need to find a way for her to be able to watch. Of course, we could just get cable... but what fun is that?!

lines.text: You will need the following materials: 1 aluminum can, something to mount the can to (I used a piece of scrap wood), coax cable and, most importantly, an impedance-matching transformer from RadioShack.
lines.text_raw: You will need the following materials: 1 aluminum can, something to mount the can to (I used a piece of scrap wood), coax cable and, most importantly, an impedance-matching transformer from RadioShack.

lines.text: First, start by cutting the soda can in half the long way with tin snips, or shears.
lines.text_raw: First, start by cutting the soda can in half the long way with tin snips, or shears.

lines.text: Mount these can halves to something to keep them in place. I used a staple gun to hold them to a piece of scrap wood.
lines.text_raw: Mount these can halves to something to keep them in place. I used a staple gun to hold them to a piece of scrap wood.

lines.text: I also attached a small-gauge wire to the inside corner of each half. This will be a pain. I had trouble soldering this part, so I sanded off the coating from the inside of the can, and folded the wire into the corner and hot-glued it down. It works pretty well, but I feel a solder joint would be better.
lines.text_raw: I also attached a small-gauge wire to the inside corner of each half. This will be a pain. I had trouble soldering this part, so I sanded off the coating from the inside of the can, and folded the wire into the corner and hot-glued it down. It works pretty well, but I feel a solder joint would be better.

lines.text: Next attach each wire to a lead on the matching transformer. I bought this transformer at RadioShack for $6.
lines.text_raw: Next attach each wire to a lead on the matching transformer. I bought [http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=2062049|this transformer] at RadioShack for $6.

lines.text: I also attached the matching transformer to the wood with an elastic band, not fancy at all.
lines.text_raw: I also attached the matching transformer to the wood with an elastic band, not fancy at all.

lines.text: Finally, attach the new antenna with a coax cable to the back of the TV. You will probably have to run a scan for channels and make sure you have the TV set to "AIR."
lines.text_raw: Finally, attach the new antenna with a coax cable to the back of the TV. You will probably have to run a scan for channels and make sure you have the TV set to "AIR."

lines.text: I have to admit mine works really well. We now get about 8 channels, all local. The picture and audio are great! I even have the antenna set up in our basement family room, which has no windows or anything. Here is a picture of the TV displaying the local weather. Not too shabby for less than $10.

guide.summary: Create an antenna for your TV to get the over-the-air TV stations for less than $10.
guide.title: Over-the-Air TV Antenna
